page.title: 18FARMING Mr.N.JENNINGS
page.content: {MR.JENNINGS}owns Lane Ends Farm.He started working as a farmer in 1941 on the family farm.He told us what farming was like when he was a young man.There was no machinery at all and everything had to be done by hand.The milk from the cows was taken by wagon in churns to Kildwick Railway Station. Horses were used until the Second World War and then tractors came in. Mr Jennings has all modern machinery now,but still milks the cows at 6-30 in the morning and 4-30 p.m.As many as 90 cows can be milked,16 at a time. There are 110 sheep on the farm and each year they can have over 200 lambs.There are also 758 hens,and a sheep-dog and lots of cats.Mr.Jennings has six farms altogether,and his two sons do most of the work nowadays.Mr. Jennings says he likes cows best of all,but he sometimes has a pet lamb.
